awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Universal Optical Tweezer Platform to Probe Nanoscale Structure and Function of Single Polymers Using Force and Optical Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is jointly supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Boston University is acquiring an optical tweezer instrument for nano-manipulation and force spectroscopy of nanoscale objects to support the research of Maria Kamenetska and colleagues Kenneth Rothschild and Keith Brown. This instrument facilitates research in the areas of chemistry, materials science, nanoscience, and biology. In general, optical tweezers are used for nano-manipulation and force spectroscopy of nanoscale objects in solution. Optical tweezers help isolate and manipulate single target molecules in an optical trap. Because trapping occurs at the focal plane of an optical microscope, light emission by the isolated molecule can be detected simultaneously with force. This allows for manipulation of materials so that mechanistic understanding of processes down to the single molecule level can be developed. This instrument enhances the educational, research, and teaching efforts of students at all levels in many departments as well as provides accessibility to this specialized science to nearby institutions. 

The award of an optical tweezer (OT) instrument for the nano-manipulation and force spectroscopy of nanoscale objects is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as chemistry, materials and nanomaterials, and biological systems. Research in chemistry and nanomaterials focus on probing the mechanical properties of and electron transport in one dimensional nanowires and two dimensional flakes. Conformational changes of single molecules in light-activated transmembrane ion channels, pumps, and sensors are studied as are structure-mechanics relationships of polymer microfibrils. Biological systems are also studied by quantifying defects in nucleosome stability at telomeric DNA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the equisition of a commercial, Lumicks C-Trap, optical tweezer single molecule force spectroscopy instrument to be housed at Boston University's Chemistry Instrumentaiton Center and used as a shared resource facility. This instrument allows for single molecule characterization of biological molecules to probe their structural and dynamic properties using force measurements. With the help of the new instrument, new methodologies were developed by the Kamenetska lab to augment established optical tweezer capabilities.

First, the Kamenetska lab developed a combined force and darkfield spectroscopy instrument that allows simultaneous force-position control and optical characterisation of single entities, like plasmonic nanoparticles. The instrument was also expanded to accomodate force measurements in non aqueous conditions.  These results were reported in 2023 (10.1021/acs.jpclett.3c00088) and have lead to further developements in the field of single particle manipulation and characterization, with applications ranging from catalysis to novel materials and characterization.

Second, the Kamenetska lab has developed a machine learning-based analysis tool to interpret the single molecule force measurements collected by the instrument. These results were published in 2024 (10.1016/j.bpj.2024.11.3320), demonstrating significant improvements in performance over existing techniques. The Python-based tool is available publicly and described in detail on the public portal zenodo.org as record # 13323961. The purchased instrument and the new methodology is spuring further investigations of biological complexes, composing DNA, RNA and/or folded proteins, implicated in human diseases such as cancer or viral infections. 

The instrument is actively used for education, specifically in an experimental class on Biological Physics at Boston University, where students learn the physics and the methodology behind the optical tweezer technique using hands-on experiments, mathematical modeling and analysis in Python. It is also actively used by graduate and undergraduate students in the Kamenetska laboratory, enabling their training in state-of-the-art single molecule techniques. These techniques are increasingly in demand both in academia, in govenment laboratories and in industry.

Both the instrument and the novel approaches developed by the Kamenetska lab continue to be available for use by the Boston University and broader community upon request.

Modified by: Maria Kamenetska
